Al-Astrulabi.description: In 10th century Syria, a Muslim woman designed a better astrolabe for navigating by the stars, earning her the name Al-Astrulabi.

Johnson.description: Katherine Johnson was an African American mathematician whose calculations played an important role in the American 1969 Moon landing.

Artemis.description: Artemis is the Greek Goddess of the Moon, wild animals, and hunting.

Hina.description: A Polynesian legend states that the goddess Hina walked along a rainbow until she reached the Moon, where she still lives.

Armstrong.description: U.S. astronaut Neil Armstrong was the first person to walk on the Moon in 1969.

Brashear.description: 19th century Pittsburghers John and Phoebe Brashear designed and built world-renowned telescopes.

Kinzler.description: Margaret developed software that made the first Moon landing possible. She later founded two software companies.

Galileo.description: 16th century Italian astronomer Galileo Galilei discovered craters and mountains on the Moon.

Tsukiyomi.description: In legends, Kaguya is discovered in a mysterious glowing bamboo stalk and grows up in Japan before returning to the Moon.

Jack and Jill.description: Leland overcame ear trauma to fly to space. He champions diversity in space careers because “talent is in every single zip code.”
